snippet.textDisplay: ❤️Reforms are much needed. ❤️India has 146 million farming families of which only 1.09 is from Punjab. So the rest of India (99.25%) of Indian farmers are open for the reforms. 💁There is no MSP here in Canada. There is no MSP for poultry, dairy in India yet those sections are thriving. Please get your facts right before just vaguely posting « I support farmer ». Fun fact: Canada complained on Indian governments subsidies to its farmers at WTO 🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣

snippet.textDisplay:
See I am An Indian. I Can say what's wrong with the farm laws.
1) Demanding for minimum support price, which helps farmers from loss.
2)Farm Law says that the farmers can sell their yield on the basis of contract which means the company which comes to farmers and says that hey we wanna buy your yield and they come to conclusion with some fixed price per kg.
But the thing here is , if anything goes fraud with this contract the farmers can not take the assistance of court.
3)The law says that the farmers can sell their yield outside APMC without paying taxes. APMC is the place where farmers sell their yield by paying some taxes at the prices at which they earn profit . If they say that they can sell their yield outside APMC , then the doors will be opened for private industrial players. Which will in turn end the APMC. If APMC ends, then The market will be under the control of private players.
4) The law says that any one can store the rice , wheat , pulses and the vegetables which can be stored for long time, without any limitations. If this happens , then the rich companies can have the power on deciding prices which will increase the prices. Basic knowledge, if they hold the food commodities in large quantities, Then there would be shortage of supply. Then the people who has this commodities will control the prices.

But the thing here is , if anything goes fraud with this contract the farmers can not take the assistance of court.
3)The law says that the farmers can sell their yield outside APMC without paying taxes. APMC is the place where farmers sell their yield by paying some taxes at the prices at which they earn profit . If they say that they can sell their yield outside APMC , then the doors will be opened for private industrial players. Which will in turn end the APMC. If APMC  ends, then The market will be under the control of private players.
4) The law says that any one can store the rice , wheat , pulses and the vegetables which can be stored for long time, without any limitations. If this happens , then the rich companies can have the power on deciding prices which will increase the prices. Basic knowledge, if they hold the food commodities in large quantities, Then there would be shortage of supply. Then the people who has this commodities will control the prices.

snippet.textDisplay:
One tiny detail was missed out, the Indian government has removed a law that made it illegal to hoard produce of a few crops. That will enable business corporates to bully the farmers to sell their produce for cheaper.....

Additionally this bill was passed in the state of Bihar a few years ago, the farmers from there make the least amount of money when compared province-wise right now.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Wheat and rice farmers of Punjab and Haryana were paid pretty low price for their crops. This happened since green revolution or before. Indian middle class and poor don't want to pay high price for grains. At the time of harvest prices are so depressed that government fix minimum price or MSP. If no MSP farmer has to throw away grains or feed to cattle. On top of it to combat high price government import agroproducts from abroad. This again depresses price. Many time Cooperatives buy agriculture products and store them. They are not capable to preserve and later sell at higher price. It's mostly burnt to get insurance money . Best solution is let farmer sell their product where ever they want to. Monsanto and Ambanis are scapegoats . Big politicians ruling coops don't want any kind of reforms.
snippet.textOriginal: Wheat and rice farmers of Punjab and Haryana were paid pretty low price for their crops. This happened since green revolution or before. Indian middle class and poor don't want to pay high price for grains. At the time of harvest prices are so depressed that government fix minimum price or MSP. If no MSP farmer has to throw away grains or feed to cattle. On top of it to combat high price government import agroproducts from abroad. This again depresses price. Many time Cooperatives buy agriculture products and store them. They are not capable to preserve and later sell at higher price. It's mostly burnt to get insurance money . Best solution is let farmer sell their product where ever they want to. Monsanto and Ambanis are scapegoats . Big politicians ruling coops don't want any kind of reforms.

snippet.textDisplay: It is really absurd. If anyone has been against Farmers on historical scale, it is Canada, and the Canadian political establishment. For years, Canada has opposed and slammed India at WTO for giving Farm Subsidies (the very thing Farmers are actually demanding). In July Trudeau posed 25 objections to why Indian government is supporting Indian farmers, saying it is impacting global agricultural trade. For years Canada has criticized supporting small and marginal farmers, by no means Trudeau is a supporter of Indian Farmers. He has questioned the support and subsidies for 65 times in last 3 years. It has challenged the very mechanism of MSP (minimum support price). So why is he suddenly in favor of something he himself has vehemently opposed so many times ? Just to appease his fringe voter base and play dirty politics. this will not end in anything good for either Trudeau or Canada. One should know better. Abusing India's farmer protest for self interest is not going to result in good result for himself in a highly open and transparent world of today. The hypocrisy is on display for the world to see.

For years, Canada has opposed and slammed India at WTO for giving Farm Subsidies (the very thing Farmers are actually demanding). For years Canada has criticized supporting small and marginal farmers, by no means Trudeau is a supporter of Indian Farmers. He has questioned the support and subsidies for 65 times in last 3 years. It has challenged the very mechanism of MSP (minimum support price). So why is he suddenly in favor of something he himself has vehemently opposed so many times ? Just to appease his fringe voter base and play dirty politics. this will not end in anything good for either Trudeau or Canada. One should know better. Abusing India's farmer protest for self interest is not going to result in good result for himself in a highly open and transparent world of today. The hypocrisy is on display for the world to see.

snippet.textDisplay: GENERAL STRIKE!  It was like my mind became an echo chamber,  ruminating that Indian business magnate Mukesh Ambani has earned "$12 million an HOUR" since the start of the pandemic. According to an interview with award winning journalist Palagummi Sainith with Amy Goodman on Democracy Now,  "If 63% of Indian farmers spent all of their income on ONLY food, minus transportation, rent, education and medicine, they still do  not have enough to feed themselves."   I appreciate Taz Dhaliwal's journal entry by adding the perspectives of both Sanjay Puparelia and Chinnaiah Jangam as they provided me with a little more to regurgitate today that I could yesterday.   When I seen the farmer beaten by a stick I reflected back on the Salt March of 1930 and wondered if Mahatma Ghandi might suggest that Capitalism is the new Colonialism, and has morphed into a greater beast?  As new reforms are legislated that take away any legal recourse of the citizen, it brings to mind, "But you have neglected the more important matters of the law; justice, mercy and faithfulness.  You should have practiced the latter without neglecting the former".  There has been an epidemic of over 20,000 farmer suicides since Monsanto and the banks started planting their seeds of wrath, and, for all the Globalist conspiracy theorist's, note that Bill Gates holds 500,000 shares of Monsanto.  I didn't know about "Mundis".
snippet.textOriginal: GENERAL STRIKE!  It was like my mind became an echo chamber,  ruminating that Indian business magnate Mukesh Ambani has earned "$12 million an HOUR" since the start of the pandemic. According to an interview with award winning journalist Palagummi Sainith with Amy Goodman on Democracy Now,  "If 63% of Indian farmers spent all of their income on ONLY food, minus transportation, rent, education and medicine, they still do  not have enough to feed themselves."   I appreciate Taz Dhaliwal's journal entry by adding the perspectives of both Sanjay Puparelia and Chinnaiah Jangam as they provided me with a little more to regurgitate today that I could yesterday.   When I seen the farmer beaten by a stick I reflected back on the Salt March of 1930 and wondered if Mahatma Ghandi might suggest that Capitalism is the new Colonialism, and has morphed into a greater beast?  As new reforms are legislated that take away any legal recourse of the citizen, it brings to mind, "But you have neglected the more important matters of the law; justice, mercy and faithfulness.  You should have practiced the latter without neglecting the former".  There has been an epidemic of over 20,000 farmer suicides since Monsanto and the banks started planting their seeds of wrath, and, for all the Globalist conspiracy theorist's, note that Bill Gates holds 500,000 shares of Monsanto.  I didn't know about "Mundis".

snippet.textDisplay:
So if I understand this, the Indian government wants to implement a free market in agriculture and we are suppose to be against this?
.
Why must government mandate minimum prices? It may be a horrible shock but it seems that farmers have become to reliant on protection. If they are worried about buyers haggling down, then they have 2 options not haggle down or leave the market.
.
Perhaps Global News should do a segment on the fact that my business gets no such protections from my government, and that it is 'abhorrent' that I too have no mandated minimum prices so as to force you to pay more for my products.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
This is very funny news 🤣
India's 50% population depends on agriculture and GDP share is just 15% . Since last 50% farmers commitig suicides due to low prices and this is clearly happening due to middleman .

This requires elementary commonsense to understand the bills are in favor of farmers as no politician in democratic country can disturb 50% population as he will lose votes .

The protesters are very tiny portion driven and funded by antisocial elements of India . Who can't see India winning their farmers .

The law makes farmers can sell their produce anywhere in the country , also make it legal for contract farming..and many such excellent reforms and whole nation is behind this .

It looks funny the way news is being sold outside India

snippet.textDisplay: The ONLY solution is to complete eradicate the mindset that has ruled India since independence from the British rule. Deep within Indian cities and villages and especially in the corporate and administration world, India has a deep rooted discrimination against and oppression of the low castes, which is justified in the name of hindu religion's doctrine. All of the farmers belong to the low caste groups and they must replace caste based hatred and join hands with the other communities falling in the category of low caste. Neither congress and nor BJP is going to be of any help and must be replaced. This is the only and only solution but this change has to start from inside a farmer's family of accepting brotherhood over the fake pride of being of a little higher caste than your fellow citizens who have also been silently suffering.

snippet.textDisplay:
The bills are not liberalising agriculture. They are giving 2 companies - AMBANI and ADANI- complete control of the agricultural market, prices, trading in futures (setting the price of the crops before they are even grown) and legal immunity from any dispute from farmers (farmers can not take grievances to court). They are legislating quotas of personal stock that the farmers are allowed to keep i.e. they are prescribing how much of the grain I grow that I can keep for myself. This is not about using the mechanism of market competition, but consolidating the power and authority of two tycoon businesses who are capturing the market in Food, Education and Healthcare at both the infrastructure and point of service level. Adani was given a contract for farmer crop insurance in the case of natural disasters a few years ago and have completely failed to adhere to contractual obligations towards farmers.

The majority of Indian Farmers are small holders with about 5-6 acres of land. They often live hand to mouth and take out loans for seeds, pesticides etc. These loans have high interest rates so they need a quick turn around on their stock and payment as soon as they harvest, lest the interest accrues to an impossible amount and they commit suicide. Like the rest of the world (e.g. USA where 40% of agriculture is subsidized by the federal government despite "liberalisation"), farmers rely on the MSP set by the government. Without this, such as in the case of these bills, it is at the behest of these 2 companies to set rates and farmers will have no choice but to sell the stock at the price set by 2 companies. Farmers are always desperate to sell their stock ASAP to pay off their loans and these Bills provide Ambani and Adani the perfect opportunity to take advantage of this and exploit farmers' vulnerability in order to capture the market.

Furthermore, these bills were passed by circumventing the legal requirements for public consultation, taking advantage of the Covid-19 lockdown. The Indian Media is nicknames "Godi Media" meaning they are in the lap of Modi. Modi is in the lap of Ambani and Adani.

There was a need for agricultural reform in India, but to empower farmers, not trap them in legal and corporate iron cages. These bills are malicious, predatory and tyrannical. They are the absolute opposite of democracy and are shameful.
snippet.textOriginal:
The bills are not liberalising agriculture. They are giving 2 companies - AMBANI and ADANI- complete control of the agricultural market, prices, trading in futures (setting the price of the crops before they are even grown) and legal immunity from any dispute from farmers (farmers can not take grievances to court). They are legislating quotas of personal stock that the farmers are allowed to keep i.e. they are prescribing how much of the grain I grow that I can keep for myself. This is not about using the mechanism of market competition, but consolidating the power and authority of two tycoon businesses who are capturing the market in Food, Education and Healthcare at both the infrastructure and point of service level.  Adani was given a contract for farmer crop insurance in the case of natural disasters a few years ago and have completely failed to adhere to contractual obligations towards farmers. 

The majority of Indian Farmers are small holders with about 5-6 acres of land. They often live hand to mouth and take out loans for seeds, pesticides etc. These loans have high interest rates so they need a quick turn around on their stock and payment as soon as they harvest, lest the interest accrues to an impossible amount and they commit suicide.  Like the rest of the world (e.g. USA where 40% of agriculture is subsidized by the federal government despite "liberalisation"),  farmers rely on the MSP set by the government. Without this, such as in the case of these bills, it is at the behest of these 2 companies to set rates and farmers will have no choice but to sell the stock at the price set by 2 companies. Farmers are always desperate to sell their stock ASAP to pay off their loans and these Bills provide Ambani and Adani the perfect opportunity to take advantage of this and exploit farmers' vulnerability in order to capture the market.

Furthermore, these bills were passed by circumventing the legal requirements for public consultation, taking advantage of the Covid-19 lockdown. The Indian Media is nicknames "Godi Media" meaning they are in the lap of Modi. Modi is in the lap of Ambani and Adani. 

There was a need for agricultural reform in India, but to empower farmers, not trap them in legal and corporate iron cages. These bills are malicious, predatory and tyrannical. They are the absolute opposite of democracy and are shameful.

snippet.textDisplay: These farmers are protesting against 3 controversial laws that were hushed through parliament in the pandemic, without consultation of the farmers. The laws are taking away the livelihood and legal rights  of the farmers in the name of 'reforms' by giving the PM's fellow Gujrati corporate giants, authority to control agriculture. The present PM has already sold various public assets to these corporates.  These new bills will push the prices up of crop in the future which will be beyond the reach of the ordinary Indian. These farmers are feeding millions free of charge through Gurdwaras, Langars when disasters occur worldwide, or at protests as we see it on YouTube. A lot of protestors and freelance  journalists are going missing. The police have arrested many by fabricating charges. It is being falsely reported that these protestors are terrorists. These farmers have sons in the army and police, guarding the dangerous indian borders, so these rich people can sleep at night. The present PM is Gujrati. Gujratis traditionally do not have soldiers that sacrifice their lives for India.  Farmers are intelligent, honest, hardworking, truthful people that trusted and voted for the BJP  government,  but now realise that they have given platform to an elected dictator. BJP, since it's election is digressing from the constitution of India by implementing anti Muslim laws, causing divisions on the ground of religion and is now portraying the Sikhs as an anti national element. This has outraged the Sikhs worldwide who have fought for the independence of India from the Mugals and British. The actions of the PM are fiercely contested by the public to the extent that the government have used tear gas, batons, barbed wired and concrete barriers to silence the protest. There are more barricades at the protests than at the borders of China.  This has got attention worldwide so now the government is trying to defend its actions. It is not rocket science to understand that when controversial  laws are forced on the public, it will cause outrage.

The present PM has already sold various public assets to these corporates.  These new bills will push the prices up of crop in the future which will be beyond the reach of the ordinary Indian. These farmers are feeding millions free of charge through Gurdwaras, Langars when disasters occur worldwide, or at protests as we see it on YouTube. BJP, since it's election is digressing from the constitution of India by implementing anti Muslim laws, causing divisions on the ground of religion and is now portraying the Sikhs as an anti national element. It is not rocket science to understand that when controversial  laws are forced on the public, it will cause outrage.

snippet.textDisplay: All these years Trudeau was the one that was fighting and accusing Indian government of protecting and subsidizing farmers (even though Indian farming policy is none of his business even remotely) and not giving them free market access. Now all of a sudden, he is 180 opposite on the issue. What a massive hypocritical joke this is. Besides the fact that he needs to worry about Canadian Farmers, not Indian Farmers. He has forcibly clamped down all kinds of protests in Canada itself, why is he even bothered about some other country ? Dose it say something about who really runs this country of Canada ?

snippet.textDisplay: So rich people want to produce food and sell it across borders. What gives poor family farmers, or anyone else, the right to stop them? The modern, free, civilized world has never moved forward by having governments intervene to force rich people to stop selling their products and poor people to stop buying them. Generally inequality is the inevitable result of people being allowed freedom of choice over their own lives, and what goes along with it is increased prosperity for everyone, as the more productive trade with the less productive and enrich their lives by doing so. Many of the poor in India who are not farmers would probably love to be able to buy their food from hugely efficient agricultural corporations, just like we do in the West. That is what makes the modern supermarket, and the incredible abundance of food in the West possible. Why should India not be more like us?
snippet.textOriginal: So rich people want to produce food and sell it across borders. What gives poor family farmers, or anyone else, the right to stop them? The modern, free, civilized world has never moved forward by having governments intervene to force rich people to stop selling their products and poor people to stop buying them. Generally inequality is the inevitable result of people being allowed freedom of choice over their own lives, and what goes along with it is increased prosperity for everyone, as the more productive trade with the less productive and enrich their lives by doing so. Many of the poor in India who are not farmers would probably love to be able to buy their food from hugely efficient agricultural corporations, just like we do in the West. That is what makes the modern supermarket, and the incredible abundance of food in the West possible. Why should India not be more like us?

snippet.textDisplay: Looks like Modi is trying to modernize farming in India. 60% of your pop farming but only 15% of GDP is a major cause of Indias continued poverty. India is facing massive threats from Chinese expansion. India has to modernize to survive. I can understand what he's trying to do but he then has to give these farmers being displaced with other new opportunities and support. Plowing your field with a wooden plow and oxen in 2020...
